body:
.dtype on a Categorical/CI should construct this

Categorica.is_dtype_equal should just work
can u run asv on this to make sure nothing much changing perf wise

> .dtype on a Categorical/CI should construct this

Ha, that's why it felt like so much less code this time, because I forgot to do the other half :)

I'll work on this a bit more today, but will probably push to 0.21
yeah this feels like it should be in 0.21.0. *maybe* we also expose this in ``pandas.api.types.CategoricalDtype`` rather than at the top-level.

Hello @TomAugspurger! Thanks for updating the PR.





















































Cheers ! There are no PEP8 issues in this Pull Request. :beers: 

##### Comment last updated on September 23, 2017 at 16:34 Hours UTC
@TomAugspurger just to check: this is ready for review?

It's close. This weekend probably. I'll submit a comment with a summary of the changes and let you know when it's really ready.

________________________________
From: Joris Van den Bossche <notifications@github.com>
Sent: Friday, August 18, 2017 5:26:43 PM
To: pandas-dev/pandas
Cc: Tom Augspurger; Mention
Subject: Re: [pandas-dev/pandas] Categorical type (#16015)


@TomAugspurger<https://github.com/tomaugspurger> just to check: this is ready for review?

—
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16015#issuecomment-323474370>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABQHIopwBcbW-elgQJliYxJ-ItR4Idswks5sZg-jgaJpZM4M-hoW>.

Alighty, this should be more or less ready for review. I have the PR split into two parts (well 3 if you count the cherry-picked 1abaecb from a separate PR)

a7eb835 has all the "new" stuff, along with tests for the new things.

f9236b4 has all the "API bending" stuff, the tests I had to update.

@jreback I'm looking into the performance now. Just micro-benchmarks at the moment, I'll follow up with more realistic ones, but on these two:

```python
# 1. single:
CategoricalDtype(range(100))

# 2. cached:
data = range(100)
x = CategoricalDtype(data)  # in the cache
CategoricalDtype(data)
```

I'm comparing two versions: caching (this branch) and no caching (essentially the same, but without the hashing of values / caching in `CategoricalDtype.__new__`).

| Kind   | Caching | No-Caching |
| ------ | ------- | ---------- |
| single | 125     | 35.6       |
| cached | 116     | 35         |

Hashing takes up about 60% of the time in the `CategoricalDtype.__new__`, so it'd be nice to avoid if possible.

---

What kind of restrictions do we have on instances of extension types being singletons (per parameter). I've been basing this off `PeriodDtype`, and we test for it, but how important is it?

I've gone ahead and removed the caching of `{hash: CategoricalDtype}` in https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16015/commits/e8dda56552a2c38b7d80c9b3a5188de815e60008

I like that it's simpler and faster, but can certainly add that back in if required. Clearly there were some issues with the hashing / caching implementation in the [old CI runs](https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/270193477#L1183)

OK, the only windows failure was on fastparquet [here](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/pandas-dev/pandas/build/1.0.4133/job/7heo6k1pjs3a6up3#L1670) has been fixed and will be in the next release of fastparqeut (next week I think). I can either skip for now or just wait till that's out. The issue was fastparquet using `str(dtype) == 'category'`, which I suppose is a breaking change, but I'm OK with it since `is_categorical_dtype` is the recommended way for checking for a Categorical, and fastparquet was setting some private properties.

@jreback @jorisvandenbossche gentle ping if you don't mind giving this a look. It'd be nice to have in master for a little while before the release.

I've skipped the fastparquet categorical tests for versions < 0.1.3 (which is all versions but master at the moment). I've tested locally against fastparquet master.
will have a look tomorrow

> how is perf?

Currently there's some issues with our internal fastpaths like `CategoricalIndex._shallow_copy` and `_simple_new`. I think I'm unnecessarily creating another instance of `CategoricalDtype` instead of passing the existing on on. Will fix that tomorrow.

Thanks Joris, I'll try to address those all this afternoon.

> General remark, I find the fact that a CategoricalDtype instance can exist without any categories/ordered specified a bit strange. But that is needed to support the case of dtype='category' where those are inferred from the data?

To be clear, the `ordered` will default to `False`, just like before. Agreed that the `categories` potentially being none is strange. I don't think users should run into it that often though... Anytime you have an actual array of categorical data, the `categories` will not be None. The only case I can imagine is where you know ahead of time that your data is ordered and sorted, but you don't know the categories?

```python
pd.read_csv("foo.csv", dtype={"A": CategoricalDtype(None, ordered=True)})
```

Which seems like a recipe for future bugs to me.

@jorisvandenbossche Agreed about not having a `fastpath` in the public API. see https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16015/commits/91752fe87f6cd5c06b7ee95b7fabb7534631a0df

Initially we used `__new__` for initialization, since we cached the instance (even though it didn't take parameters). That commit cleans things up a bit.

Correct, and I don't plan to deprecate `dtype'category'`.

On Mon, Sep 18, 2017 at 5:55 AM, Joris Van den Bossche <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@jorisvandenbossche* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In doc/source/categorical.rst
> <https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16015#discussion_r139390284>:
>
> > +should be inferred from whatever is present in the data when the
> +:class:`pandas.Categorical` is created.
> +
> +.. ipython:: python
> +
> +   from pandas.api.types import CategoricalDtype
> +
> +   CategoricalDtype(['a', 'b', 'c'])
> +   CategoricalDtype(['a', 'b', 'c'], ordered=True)
> +   CategoricalDtype()
> +
> +A :class:`~pandas.api.types.CategoricalDtype` can be used in any place pandas
> +expects a `dtype`. For example :func:`pandas.read_csv`,
> +:func:`pandas.DataFrame.astype`, or in the Series constructor.
> +
> +As a convenience, you can use the string ``'category'`` in place of a
>
> Yes, but you didn't do that actual deprecation (or not yet)?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16015#discussion_r139390284>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABQHItygdUADe7vz66Heen2kIDzUzdl9ks5sjkwVgaJpZM4M-hoW>
> .
>

> Yes, but you didn't do that actual deprecation (or not yet)?

I don't think this is desirable, 'category' is a nice convenience

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16015/commits/416d1d7b9ce81287a1b7f2802751dca1fdeb5084 has the changes to `Categorical.__init__` that you requested @jreback. It's a bit messy since there are basically 3 ways for specifying the categories

1. passing `dtype=CategoricalDtype(...)`
2. passing `categories=...`
3. passing a `Categorical` for `values`

I think all three are useful and (hopefully) well-tested now. I'll update the docstring to indicate the priority (basically moving that comment to the docstring)

Thanks. I fixed up the doc comments. I'll merge on green and do the other
followups later today.

> +^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

> +:class:`pandas.api.types.CategoricalDtype` has been added to the public API and
> +expanded to include the ``categories`` and ``ordered`` attributes. A
> +``CategoricalDtype`` can be used to specify the set of categories and
> +orderedness of an array, independent of the data themselves. This can be useful,
> +e.g., when converting string data to a ``Categorical`` (:issue:`14711`, :issue:`15078`):
